episodeTitle: Explore! A Kingdom of Love and Passion - Dressrosa!
description: The Straw Hat Pirates, Law, Kin'emon, and Momonosuke arrive at Dressrosa and split into three groups. Luffy's team explores the colorful town filled with living toys, while a mysterious blind gambler is cheated by thugs in a casino.

events.title: Arrival at Dressrosa
events.description: The Straw Hat Pirates, along with Trafalgar Law, Kin'emon, and Momonosuke, arrive at the island of Dressrosa, known as the Kingdom of Love and Passion. They see the colorful island and prepare to dock at the port town of Acacia.
events.significance: Marks the beginning of the Dressrosa Arc, one of the longest and most important arcs in One Piece. This island will be central to the crew's alliance with Law and their plan to take down Doflamingo.

quotes.text: So this is Dressrosa, the Kingdom of Love and Passion!
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: First sight of Dressrosa from the sea

events.title: Crew Divides into Three Teams
events.description: Law carefully organizes the crew into three strategic groups: Team A (Luffy, Zoro, Sanji, Kin'emon, and Franky) will explore the town; Team B (Chopper, Nami, Brook, and Momonosuke) will guard the Thousand Sunny; Team C (Law, Robin, and Usopp) will take Caesar Clown to Green Bit to meet Doflamingo.
events.significance: This strategic split sets up the complex narrative structure of the Dressrosa Arc, where multiple storylines unfold simultaneously across different locations. Law's careful planning shows his tactical approach to confronting Doflamingo.

quotes.text: Listen carefully. We need to split into three groups for this operation.
quotes.speaker: Trafalgar Law

events.title: Kin'emon Provides Disguises
events.description: Kin'emon uses his Devil Fruit ability to create disguises for the crew members, giving them black suits and fake beards to blend in with the locals of Dressrosa. The disguises are comically old-fashioned and draw mixed reactions from the crew.
events.significance: Showcases Kin'emon's Fuku Fuku no Mi ability and adds comedic relief while highlighting the samurai's earnest attempt to help the crew maintain a low profile in enemy territory.

quotes.text: These are the proper disguises for warriors visiting foreign lands!
quotes.speaker: Kin'emon

events.title: Introduction of Living Toys
events.description: As the exploration team enters Dressrosa's streets, they witness the island's most distinctive feature: sentient toys living and working alongside humans. These toys interact naturally with citizens, play games, and even have jobs.
events.significance: This mystery is central to the Dressrosa Arc's plot. The toys are actually humans transformed by Sugar's Hobi Hobi no Mi ability, though this truth won't be revealed until much later. This scene plants the seeds for one of the arc's biggest reveals.

quotes.text: Whoa! The toys are moving and talking! This place is amazing!
quotes.speaker: Luffy

events.title: Admiral Fujitora's First Appearance (Blind Gambler)
events.description: A blind man in simple robes is introduced walking through the streets of Dressrosa. He asks Zoro for directions to a gambling house. The man carries a cane that conceals a sword and exudes a calm, mysterious presence.
events.significance: This is the anime debut of Admiral Issho, also known as Fujitora, one of the two admirals recruited during the timeskip. His introduction as a humble blind gambler conceals his true identity and power, creating dramatic irony for viewers who don't yet know he's a Marine Admiral.

quotes.text: Excuse me, young man. Could you direct me to the nearest gambling establishment?
quotes.speaker: Fujitora

events.title: Zoro's Instinctive Wariness
events.description: After directing the blind man, Zoro pauses and looks back with a serious expression. Despite the man's harmless appearance, Zoro's instincts tell him something is unusual about this person.
events.significance: Demonstrates Zoro's honed battle instincts and ability to sense powerful individuals. This moment foreshadows Fujitora's true identity and establishes that even disguised, an Admiral's presence can be felt by strong fighters.

events.title: Fujitora Cheated at Gambling
events.description: At a restaurant casino, the blind man sits at a roulette table. Three of Doflamingo's thugs recognize his blindness as an opportunity and begin cheating him, manipulating the game to steal his money while mocking him.
events.significance: This scene serves multiple purposes: it establishes Dressrosa's underlying corruption beneath its beautiful facade, shows Doflamingo's crew's cruelty, and sets up Fujitora's character as someone who faces injustice. The scene also tests whether anyone will stand up against wrongdoing.

quotes.text: Hehe, this blind fool doesn't know what's happening. Let's take him for everything he's got!
quotes.speaker: Doflamingo's Thug

events.title: Law's Team Prepares for Green Bit
events.description: Trafalgar Law, Usopp, Robin, and the captured Caesar Clown prepare to head north across a bridge to Green Bit, where they will meet Doflamingo to exchange Caesar for Doflamingo's resignation from the Warlords.
events.significance: Sets up the central conflict of the arc. This mission is Law's primary objective and represents a critical confrontation with one of the arc's main antagonists. The scene builds tension for what's to come.

quotes.text: Remember, this is a dangerous mission. Stay alert and be ready for anything.
quotes.speaker: Trafalgar Law
quotes.context: Briefing his team before heading to Green Bit

events.title: Dressrosa's Passionate Culture Displayed
events.description: The episode showcases Dressrosa's vibrant culture, with passionate flamenco dancers, lively music, colorful architecture, and citizens expressing love and emotion openly. The island appears as a paradise, though subtle hints suggest darkness beneath the surface.
events.significance: Establishes the contrast between Dressrosa's beautiful appearance and the dark truth that will be uncovered throughout the arc. The passionate culture masks the tragedy of the toys and Doflamingo's tyrannical rule.

events.title: Momonosuke and Luffy's Argument
events.description: Before the teams split, Luffy tries to make Momonosuke transform into his dragon form again, but Momonosuke insists he can't remember how to fly and refuses. The two argue about whether Momonosuke is being a coward, with Momonosuke declaring that a samurai fears nothing.
events.significance: Develops Momonosuke's character and his pride as a samurai's son. Also hints at his incomplete control over his artificial Devil Fruit powers and builds the relationship dynamic between him and Luffy.

quotes.text: I am no coward! A samurai of Wano fears nothing!
quotes.speaker: Momonosuke
quotes.context: Defending his honor against Luffy's teasing

themes.description: Dressrosa appears as a beautiful paradise with passionate people and magical living toys, but beneath this facade lies Doflamingo's tyrannical rule and the tragedy of transformed humans.
themes.symbolism: The living toys represent the hidden victims of oppression, appearing cheerful while their humanity has been stolen.

themes.description: The episode introduces themes of justice through Fujitora being cheated and Law's plan to bring down Doflamingo, questioning what justice means in a corrupt world.
themes.symbolism: Fujitora's blindness symbolizes both his literal inability to see and metaphorically represents justice being blind.

themes.description: Law's careful strategic planning and organization of teams highlights the importance of coordination and tactics when facing powerful enemies.
themes.symbolism: The three-team split represents different approaches to the same goal, showing that complex problems require multifaceted solutions.

mangaDifferences.difference: In the manga, Fujitora is first shown being cheated at the restaurant. The anime added a scene of him having a casual stroll through Acacia and asking Zoro for directions before reaching the gambling house.
The anime adds Brook saying he wants to call the samurais 'pervs' instead of 'warriors' right after Sanji's angry reaction to Kin'emon's 'like father, like son' statement.

After Kin'emon shows his idea of Dressrosa clothing, the anime has Nami whack Kin'emon, Sanji, AND Brook, while it was just Kin'emon and Sanji in the manga. Momonosuke is also shown terrified of Nami after her outburst.
While Law shows the crew a map of Dressrosa in the anime, Luffy and Momonosuke are not shown fighting with each other like they were in the manga.
In the manga, Chopper and Robin were still on the Sunny while Luffy was talking to Momonosuke. In the anime, they were off the ship.

trivia.fact: This episode adapts Chapter 701, pages 2-16, marking the beginning of the Dressrosa Arc, which would become one of the longest arcs in One Piece anime history, spanning 118 episodes (629-746).
Admiral Fujitora (Issho) is voiced by Ikuya Sawaki in Japanese and Charles Campbell in English. Sawaki was born on August 25, 1951, making him 62 years old at the time of this episode's airing.
The opening theme 'Wake up!' by AAA debuted in episode 629 and continued through episode 686, making it one of the longer-running opening themes in One Piece.
This episode had no ending theme. Ending themes were discontinued from episode 279 and weren't reinstated until episode 1071, a gap of over 17 years, to allow for longer openings.
Episode 630 aired in the US via simulcast on January 25, 2014, one day before its Japanese broadcast on January 26, 2014, due to time zone differences.
The Japanese title of this episode is '冒険！愛と情熱の国ドレスローザ' (Bōken! Ai to Jōnetsu no Kuni Doresurōza), which directly translates to 'Adventure! The Country of Love and Passion, Dressrosa.'
Dressrosa's design is heavily inspired by Spanish culture, particularly cities like Barcelona, with flamenco dancing, passionate music, and Mediterranean architecture featured prominently.
The episode received a TV rating of 8.8% in Japan and ranked 3rd in viewership for its time slot, showing strong audience interest in the new arc.
